body: The doc for this is [here](https://github.com/IBM-Bluemix/docs/pull/169) @rabbah

the main thing that i think is missing here is the link between the `content_type` and `encoding` and `payload` fields. the former two define the interpretation of the latter, and yet this relation is not explicit in the metadata.

it'd be nice if the there were siblings in the input, e.g.

```
{ { payload: xxx, encoding: "base64", content_type: "audio/wav" }, ... }
```

but i realize that our annotations do not yet support specifications beyond the top level of nesting.

perhaps this is an issue better solved with a custom invoke/bind page, but... i don't think i could take the annotations as they exist and automatically generate, i.e. by interpreting the annotations, an invoke/instantiate/bind UI that would let the user invoke this action.

the sampleOutput here doesn't seem to align with the input specifications for speech-to-text..

in particular, in stt, there is a `content_type` input parameter. whereas in tts there is a metadata: { mimetype: "..." } structure. at the very least, wouldn't it be nice to have the same field names? e.g.

```
sampleOutput: { payload: xxx, encoding: "base64", content_type: "audio/wav" }
```

re: rich data, this PR has the same potential issues as with #277, the stt PR, though perhaps the issue is less egregious here. the issue is that that triple of fields really conveys one piece of data; i.e. the data values of those latter two fields are actually "runtime annotations" on a third parameter, rather than being first-class data values.

it also just occurred to me that the need to encode the binary (speech) payload... it'd be nice to avoid this, but doing so may require backend support that doesn't exist? i'm not sure how whisk can pass through unencoded binary data to nodejs without some sort of special support.

because, as far as my (quite possibly flawed) understanding goes: nodejs, the only way to have this kind of data is to keep it off-heap (that's what the Buffer abstraction gives you)
looks good to me

Do you mean just the latter (submit them to github)? Improving the docs for working with packages otherwise should complement and extend this https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/packages.md#creating-a-package for example.

One thing to keep in mind is that packages do not need to be in this git repository. In fact as others create packages they surely won't be.

you can go with this command:
wsk rule status name

what about this, as a first stab for defining terminology? any feedback welcome, pls feel free to throw tomatoes :-)

feed — a feed implements the knowledge for how to setup receiving events from a particular source. for instance, a github feed knows how to setup github webhooks, a cloudant feed knows how to configure cloudant for sending events about data changes.

trigger — a trigger is created to express the interest in a particular event — it specifies all information needed to let the trigger fire whenever an event occurs. triggers are always created based on feeds. for instance, someone might create a trigger for their specific github account, such that the trigger always fires when a new file is committed.

A problem here is that the Watson API uses "accept" for text-to-speech input, yet uses "content_type" for in speech-to-text input, and I'm mirroring the Watson API. I can, however, remove the metadata field in text-to-speech output so that it matches the input of speech-to-text (so "accept" in tts input would be the same as "content_type" in tts output). The end product would look like this:

Text to speech

```
    -a sampleInput '{"payload":"Hello, world.", "encoding":"base64", "accept":"audio/wav", "username":"XXX", "password":"XXX" }' \
    -a sampleOutput '{"payload":"<base64 encoding of a .wav file>", "encoding":"base64", "content_type":"audio/wav"}'
```

Speech to text

```
    -a sampleInput '{"payload":"<base64 encoding of a wav file>", "encoding":"base64", "content_type":"audio/wav", "username":"XXX", "password":"XXX"}' \
    -a sampleOutput '{"data":"Hello."}'
```

Anyone have objections?
looks good, thanks!
LGTM !
Ok, it has been updated.

The implementation does not create an activation resource until the activation is completed. So a GET for a "valid" activation id which is received as part of a non-blocking invoke will return `404` (Not Found) until the activation completes. The controller will need to create an activation resource for the id with an appropriate `status` (e.g., marked `pending`) field.

The CLI or UI could report a tip along the lines of "did you request an activation record for a recent activation that may not have finished? if so, try again" but we should just fix it at the controller level.

In general, most times the person doing the merge can rebase and ff without resolving conflicts. This avoids the added overhead of constantly rebasing. Unless you know there is a conflict, you can skip rebasing. Since we don't use the `merge` button.

Maybe we should visit the docs folder structure

I think we need to have different sub directories per end user of the docs.
- User documentation (just using openwhisk)
- Contributor documentation (a developer making contributions to the repo), I would name this "Developer docs" but that could get confuse with user docs, which is also a developer focusing in something else.
- Integrator documentation (operations, running on a server, deploying, i.e. setup and run openwhisk in production)

Maybe have a directory structure like:

```
docs/user/
docs/contributor/ 
docs/operator/
```

The testing docs can be located in **Contributor documentation**
Docs how to submit a patch, create tests, and run the test

@mrutkows Thanks for the correction. It's customary when working with open projects to fork the project and submit a pull request from a branch of your own fork. We follow this convention in our project. We probably should explicitly add a link to these guidelines (e.g., Pull Request Pro Tips) https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/ from our contributing document.

A "document not found" from the controller's point of view is invariably not an error. In the invoker, it is invariably always an error. Viewed in this way, yes. Of course there are other operation, which if they fail should generate an error-level log message (connection failure for example).

Hi @ChrBi can you do that work and take it to completion, to check if the tutorial works, and modify it to match the specifications I describe in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/403#issue-154506045 ?

I don't think is practical since a feed keeps sending events and firing triggers for the same feed, knowing that all are trigger is hard to define without saving state.

For example take web page, imaging that you want to  run a single action only with a set of events fire.

For example Q key is press, A key press and Z key press

Now start pressing all 3 keys like crazy :-)

The events will not be fire at the same time, and will be multiple of each.

Now do you want to run the action when? 

The first time Q, A, Z are press no matter the order? 

I think user can implement today with current low level construct we have, by saving state/storage like a counter, increase until reach 3, then reset to 0 & fire a trigger for action to run.
one action will be in charge of increasing the counter and firing the trigger for the final rule that wants to run the action only when the 3 events have occurred

maybe I'm wrong and don't understand the use case.

I agree it can be implemented with our current API, but I think it will have some overhead. So the real question is whether there are enough use cases like this one to justify us dealing with managing the state of the triggers instead of the user of our system.
Add a print statement on retry and something indicating what failed.  Test build?
